[http://www.flickr.com/photos/kjbeath] The road in the photo is the Bradfield Highway, and blissfully - no traffic jams!
Fort Street Girls High school  (photo above), was located at Fort St, Millers Point near Observatory Hill, opened in 1849  and closed in 1975,
and the girls moved to the former Fort Street Boys High on a different Fort Street and  Parramatta Road, Petersham, renamed as  Fort Street High School.

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content:
Hello AndyBrii. The old Fort Street Girls' High School, now part of the National Trust, is just south of the buildings that were marooned on the circular Cahill Expressway loop, although you could say it was also effectively marooned. 
The photo is around 9 months after the Harbour Bridge opened. The curved "unfinished" area in the foreground is the roof of the tram tunnels headed from the Bridge to Wynyard under York Street. You can see their alignment in the aerial photo you supplied. The railway tunnels would be adjacent and under the roadway. 
Picture of the foreground area here in 1901, the Grand Hotel on the left sat on the south west corner of Essex St, and Essex Street ran straight through dead-centre to the Fort Street High School building. So, the Grand Hotel would have sat in the foreground of the top picture, and that's probably the hotel footings showing.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8189453150/in/photostream/]
